scenario: Over the past 60 trading days, a mid-cap stock shows a recurring pattern: on days when the stock’s first-hour trading volume is in the top quartile of its own 60-day history, the stock’s closing-to-closing realized volatility tends to be higher than on days when first-hour volume is in the bottom quartile. A student analyst summarizes this with a scatter plot of first-hour volume vs. same-day realized volatility and reports a positive correlation. The analyst has not claimed any mechanism (e.g., news releases, earnings, or macro announcements), and the dataset does not explicitly mark which days had major information events. The analyst wants to use the pattern as a descriptive observation about the stock’s behavior, not as a causal claim about what would happen if volume were forced to change.
claim: Days with higher first-hour trading volume are associated with higher same-day realized volatility for this stock.
label: YES

variables.X: First-hour trading volume (relative to the stock’s 60-day distribution)
variables.Y: Same-day realized volatility (close-to-close or intraday measure)

causal_structure: Pure association statement with no intervention or counterfactual.
key_insight: The claim is explicitly correlational and matches the described observation; no causal leap is made.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: N/A
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: N/A

wise_refusal: This is a descriptive association, not evidence that increasing volume would cause volatility to rise. The relationship could be driven by shared drivers like news or market-wide shocks, and the pattern could change in other regimes. A causal claim would require an identification strategy (e.g., natural experiment or instrument) or a structural model of trading and volatility.
gold_rationale: L1 case: correctly stated observational association; Z variables noted but do not invalidate an association claim.

scenario: A researcher compiles weekly data for 120 weeks on a set of investment-grade corporate bonds. They compute each week’s average bid-ask spread across the sample and the sample’s average credit spread over Treasuries. In the weeks where average credit spreads are higher, the researcher also observes that average bid-ask spreads are generally wider. They present summary statistics showing that the top tercile of weeks by credit spread has a higher mean bid-ask spread than the bottom tercile. The data are purely observational and do not separate changes driven by macro conditions (e.g., rate volatility) from issuer-specific news. The researcher wants to report a descriptive co-movement pattern, but a colleague interprets it as “wider credit spreads make bonds illiquid.”
claim: Weeks with higher average credit spreads are associated with wider average bid-ask spreads in this bond sample.
label: YES

variables.X: Average credit spread over Treasuries (weekly, sample average)

causal_structure: Association between two observables potentially driven by common shocks.
key_insight: The claim is an association and is supported by the described summary pattern; causal direction is intentionally not asserted.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: N/A
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: N/A

wise_refusal: This pattern alone doesn’t establish whether higher credit spreads cause illiquidity, illiquidity raises observed credit spreads, or both respond to a shared shock (e.g., risk-off regimes or dealer constraints). Market equilibrium and selection effects can change which bonds trade and how spreads are measured. To support a causal claim, you’d need a credible identification strategy (instrument, policy shock, or structural liquidity-credit model).
gold_rationale: L1 case: valid descriptive association; designed to tempt a causal interpretation but the claim stays at L1.

scenario: A portfolio manager rolled out a new trading algorithm (X) intended to increase the returns (Y) of their equity portfolio. Around the same time, a well-followed sell-side analyst published a bullish recommendation (Z) on many of the same names. The manager notes that the stocks traded using the new algorithm posted higher returns after the recommendation, and points to this co-movement as evidence the algorithm caused the return increase.
claim: Implementing the new trading algorithm caused the portfolio’s equity returns to increase.
label: NO

variables.X: New trading algorithm implementation (on selected equity names)
variables.Y: Equity portfolio returns over the evaluation window
Z: Bullish analyst recommendation affecting the same names

causal_structure: Selection/conditioning on a post-recommendation set of names can induce spurious correlation between X and Y via Z-related filtering (collider/selection).
key_insight: If performance is evaluated on a subset defined by Z (recommended names), conditioning can create a non-causal link between the algorithm and returns.
hidden_timestamp: Whether the evaluation/selection set was restricted to (or defined by) stocks that received the analyst recommendation (Z), rather than all eligible portfolio names.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the analysis conditions on the recommended subset (e.g., only names that received Z), the algorithm-return relationship can be distorted by selection and the return bump may primarily reflect Z rather than X. In that case, the causal claim is not supported; label remains NO.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the analysis uses a pre-specified universe and compares algorithm-on vs algorithm-off in a way not conditioned on Z (e.g., randomized or matched with clear controls), Z becomes a confounder to address rather than a selection collider. Even then, without an identification strategy, the causal claim is still not established; label remains NO.

wise_refusal: I can’t endorse the causal claim without knowing whether the evaluation conditioned on the recommended subset and without a credible identification design. In market settings, selection and equilibrium responses (routing, attention, liquidity) can shift distributions and induce spurious relationships. You’d need a randomized rollout, a natural experiment, or a structural execution/returns model that accounts for recommendation-driven demand to support causality.
gold_rationale: L2 asks whether an intervention caused Y. Here, the observed post-change returns coincide with an analyst recommendation that can drive returns and can also define the evaluation subset, creating selection/collider bias. Without an identification strategy separating X from Z-driven effects, the causal claim is invalid.

scenario: A futures trader deployed a new algorithmic strategy (X) to profit from oil futures price fluctuations (Y). After deployment, the trader recorded higher returns. During the same period, an unexpected geopolitical event (Z) changed oil supply expectations and moved oil futures prices sharply. The trader attributes the higher returns to the strategy rollout.
claim: Deploying the new algorithmic strategy caused the increase in oil futures trading returns.
label: NO

variables.Y: Oil futures trading returns during the evaluation window
Z: Unexpected geopolitical event affecting oil supply expectations

causal_structure: Z → Y and Z may also influence X’s profitability/usage; naive before/after attribution confounds X with Z.
key_insight: A concurrent shock can drive returns directly; without isolating X from Z, you cannot infer a causal effect.
hidden_timestamp: Whether the geopolitical shock (Z) occurred before the bulk of the measured return improvement and whether returns were compared to a valid counterfactual period/control unaffected by Z.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If Z preceded the measured improvement and materially moved oil prices/volatility, the return increase could be primarily shock-driven rather than strategy-driven. Without controls, the causal claim fails; label remains NO.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If X had a staged rollout with a clean control (e.g., identical instruments/time windows not traded by X) and returns improved even absent Z-like shocks, that would strengthen a causal argument. But as described, no such identification is provided; label remains NO.

wise_refusal: I can’t credit causality because a major geopolitical shock changes the return distribution and induces equilibrium responses (liquidity, volatility, order flow). The scenario provides no valid counterfactual, control group, or randomization. You’d need a natural experiment, diff-in-diff with unaffected contracts, or a structural trading PnL decomposition to attribute the gain to X.
gold_rationale: An intervention claim is made, but a simultaneous exogenous shock plausibly explains the outcome. With no design to separate X from Z, the causal claim is invalid.

scenario: A hedge fund increased its allocation to technology sector options (X) to profit from anticipated earnings surprises (Y). Over the same window, the fund’s returns from these options increased. At the same time, market-wide technology sector volatility (Z) rose sharply due to macro news, which can raise option premia and affect strategy payoffs. The fund concludes the allocation change caused the return improvement.
claim: Increasing allocation to technology sector options caused the fund’s returns to improve.
label: NO

variables.X: Increased allocation to technology sector options
variables.Y: Fund returns attributable to those options in the evaluation window
Z: Market-wide increase in technology sector volatility

causal_structure: Z can drive both the decision to tilt into options (X) and the returns (Y), making the observed effect non-causal.
key_insight: If X is a response to volatility, then Z drives both X and Y; before/after attribution is invalid.
hidden_timestamp: Whether the allocation increase (X) was decided/executed before the volatility spike (Z) or in response to it.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If X was implemented prior to the volatility increase and the strategy’s payoff is linked to the allocation change rather than volatility regime, that could support causality. But no design is described, so the claim still lacks identification; label remains NO.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If X was implemented in response to Z, then Z is driving both the allocation and subsequent returns, and the causal interpretation is invalid. Label remains NO.

wise_refusal: I can’t accept the causal conclusion without timing clarity and an identification strategy. Volatility regime shifts change equilibrium option pricing, hedging costs, and order flow composition, which can mechanically raise or lower returns independent of skill. You’d need a pre-registered rollout, control portfolio, or structural attribution separating volatility beta from allocation effects.
gold_rationale: This is an L2 causal claim but timing/selection suggests reverse causation and confounding by volatility regime. Without a credible counterfactual, the claim is invalid.

scenario: A credit derivatives PM introduced a hedging strategy (X) that dynamically adjusts CDS positions based on market-implied volatility to reduce portfolio volatility (Y). Over six months, portfolio volatility declined. Over the same period, credit spreads broadly tightened across sectors (Z), which can reduce CDS mark-to-market risk and also influence the signals used by the strategy.
claim: The new dynamic CDS hedging strategy caused the decline in portfolio volatility.
label: NO

variables.X: Dynamic CDS hedging strategy based on market-implied volatility
variables.Y: Portfolio volatility over the evaluation period
Z: Broad decline in credit spreads across sectors

causal_structure: Z can change both underlying risk and how volatility signals/portfolio volatility are measured, biasing attribution to X.
key_insight: If risk declines due to market tightening, volatility falls regardless of X; additionally, signal/measurement changes can overstate X’s effect.
hidden_timestamp: Whether the spread tightening (Z) materially altered the volatility inputs or the volatility measurement used to evaluate Y, relative to the pre-strategy baseline.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If Z changed the measurement of implied volatility inputs or the volatility metric used for Y (e.g., mechanically lower vol from tightening), then the observed decline could be largely measurement/market-driven rather than causal impact of X. Label remains NO.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If measurement is consistent and a valid control (e.g., shadow portfolio without X) shows no similar decline despite Z, that would strengthen a causal argument. But the scenario provides no such control, so label remains NO.

wise_refusal: I can’t assign causality because broad spread tightening changes both true risk and measured risk, and traders/markets adapt in equilibrium. Without a stable measurement approach and a credible counterfactual (control, random rollout, or structural model), the decline in volatility can’t be attributed to X. Evidence from matched controls or structural CDS risk decomposition is needed.
gold_rationale: The intervention coincides with a market-wide tightening that plausibly reduces volatility and may alter measurement. No design isolates X, so the causal claim is invalid.

scenario: A derivatives trading firm adopted a new volatility forecasting model (X) to improve trading strategy performance and returns (Y) on volatility-linked products. After implementation, reported returns improved. At the same time, investor risk sentiment shifted (Z), altering demand for volatility products and potentially changing realized returns regardless of forecasting quality.
claim: Implementing the new volatility forecasting model caused the improvement in returns on volatility products.
label: NO

variables.Y: Returns on volatility-linked products over the evaluation window
Z: Shift in investor risk sentiment affecting volatility demand/pricing

causal_structure: Z affects Y directly and can influence adoption/usage/profitability of X, confounding attribution.
key_insight: A regime shift in sentiment can move vol premia and payoffs, swamping model effects absent controls.
hidden_timestamp: Whether the sentiment shift (Z) preceded the performance improvement and whether the evaluation compares against a valid counterfactual not exposed to the same Z-driven regime change.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If Z changed the volatility risk premium during the same evaluation window, improved returns could be mainly regime-driven rather than model-driven. Without controls, label remains NO.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the firm can show out-of-sample improvement versus a baseline model on the same trades while holding exposure constant, that would support causality. The scenario does not provide such evidence, so label remains NO.

wise_refusal: I can’t credit the model as causal because risk sentiment shifts change equilibrium pricing, flow, and the distribution of outcomes for volatility products. Without a controlled backtest with fixed exposures or a natural experiment, improved returns could be driven by Z. A structural model or randomized A/B deployment would be needed to isolate X.
gold_rationale: Concurrent regime changes confound the intervention. No identification strategy is given; therefore the causal claim is invalid.

scenario: A structured products desk adopted a new volatility forecasting model (X) to improve pricing accuracy of structured notes (Y) over six months. Over the same timeframe, overall market liquidity increased (Z), potentially narrowing spreads and improving observed pricing outcomes independent of the model’s accuracy.
claim: Adopting the new volatility forecasting model caused pricing accuracy of the structured notes to improve.
label: NO

variables.X: Volatility forecasting model adoption for pricing
variables.Y: Observed pricing accuracy over the evaluation window
Z: Increase in market liquidity affecting pricing/hedging conditions

key_insight: Time-varying liquidity can improve measured pricing outcomes even if the model adds no value.
hidden_timestamp: Whether liquidity conditions (Z) improved at or before the observed pricing improvement and whether pricing accuracy is evaluated in a way comparable across liquidity regimes.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If Z improved materially at the same time and pricing accuracy is judged using market quotes affected by liquidity, the improvement could be largely Z-driven rather than due to X. Label remains NO.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If pricing accuracy is evaluated on a standardized metric (e.g., ex-post hedging PnL with fixed methodology) and improves versus a baseline under the same liquidity regime, X could matter. The scenario provides no such controlled evidence; label remains NO.

wise_refusal: I can’t endorse causality because liquidity regimes change equilibrium spreads, quote quality, and the measurement of ‘accuracy.’ The scenario lacks a stable evaluation design or a control model/desk. You’d need a controlled backtest, A/B deployment, or a structural model that separates model error from liquidity-driven quote changes.
gold_rationale: This is an intervention claim, but time-varying liquidity confounds the before/after comparison. Without identification or stable measurement, the causal claim is invalid.

scenario: A hedge fund introduced a policy (X) requiring traders to maximize daily NAV changes to increase short-term returns (Y). After implementing the policy, reported short-term returns rose. Meanwhile, there was increased investor demand (Z) for high-frequency strategies, which could change market conditions and the payoff profile of short-horizon trading regardless of the internal policy.
claim: The NAV-maximization policy caused the increase in the fund’s short-term returns.
label: NO

variables.X: Policy requiring traders to maximize daily NAV changes
variables.Y: Short-term fund returns after policy adoption
Z: Market-wide increase in demand for high-frequency trading strategies

causal_structure: Optimizing a proxy metric can change behavior/risks; external demand shift Z can also affect returns, confounding attribution.
key_insight: Maximizing a metric can change strategy risk-taking and can look successful in certain regimes; without risk-adjusted evaluation and controls, causality is unsupported.
hidden_timestamp: Whether return improvements persist after controlling for risk exposure/strategy composition changes induced by the metric-targeting policy and whether Z changed the market opportunity set at the same time.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the policy increased hidden risk-taking or changed positions (e.g., leverage/turnover) and the returns reflect a regime favorable to those exposures, the observed gain may not be a true causal improvement in skill. Label remains NO.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If returns improve on a risk-adjusted basis with unchanged exposure and versus a credible control group during the same regime, that would strengthen causality. The scenario does not establish this, so label remains NO.

wise_refusal: I can’t attribute the return increase to the policy because Goodhart dynamics and equilibrium changes can shift strategy composition and risk, and a concurrent demand shift changes the opportunity set. Without risk-adjusted controls and a credible counterfactual, the causal claim isn’t justified. Evidence like a controlled rollout, matched desks, or a structural performance attribution model is needed.
gold_rationale: The policy targets a proxy (daily NAV changes) and may alter behavior; concurrent market shifts also affect returns. No identification is provided, so the causal claim is invalid.

scenario: A proprietary trading firm introduced a new execution algorithm (X) to reduce trade execution costs (Y) by optimizing order timing and placement. label: NO

variables.Y: Average trade execution cost during the evaluation period
Z: Decline in market volatility affecting spreads/slippage

causal_structure: Z affects execution costs directly and may coincide with X rollout; before/after attribution confounds X with Z.

hidden_timestamp: Whether cost reductions persist when comparing to a matched control period/instruments with similar volatility, or when holding volatility constant in evaluation.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If cost reductions appear only in the low-volatility regime and disappear when matched on volatility, the effect is likely Z-driven and not causal from X. Label remains NO.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If costs drop relative to a baseline algorithm on the same trades with exposure held constant and volatility matched, X could be credited. The scenario does not provide that evidence, so label remains NO.

wise_refusal: I can’t accept a causal conclusion because volatility changes shift equilibrium spreads and liquidity, altering costs regardless of execution logic. The scenario lacks matched controls or a stable evaluation design. A randomized A/B test across orders, diff-in-diff versus a control desk, or a structural cost attribution would be required.
gold_rationale: The intervention coincides with a volatility decline that can lower costs by itself; without identification, the causal claim is invalid.

scenario: A high-frequency trading firm introduced a new latency arbitrage strategy (X) aimed at improving profit margins (Y) around macro announcements. conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If performance is measured primarily during low-liquidity conditions when spreads widen, higher profits may reflect Z-driven opportunity rather than X. Label remains NO.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the firm evaluates identical announcement windows with and without X (or against a control strategy) across comparable liquidity regimes, that would strengthen causal attribution. The scenario does not establish such a design; label remains NO.

wise_refusal: I can’t endorse causality because liquidity conditions change equilibrium spreads and the distribution of profitable opportunities, and performance evaluation can be selected on those conditions. Without randomized rollout or matched controls, profitability could be regime-driven. You’d need an A/B deployment, diff-in-diff with control windows, or a structural microstructure model to isolate X.
gold_rationale: Selection on evaluation windows and concurrent liquidity regime changes undermine causal attribution. No identification is provided, so the claim is invalid.

scenario: A market-making desk implemented a high-frequency trading algorithm (X) aimed at increasing profit margins (Y). Around the same time, regulatory changes reduced market-wide transaction costs (Z). The desk reports improved profit margins and attributes the change to the new algorithm.

label: NO
causal_structure: Z reduces costs and can raise margins directly while coinciding with X rollout; naive attribution confounds X with Z.
key_insight: Market-wide fee changes can explain higher margins without implying the algorithm caused them.
hidden_timestamp: Whether the regulatory cost reduction (Z) took effect before the profit increase and whether the evaluation separates algorithm effects from fee effects.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If Z took effect before or during the measured margin improvement and margins rose broadly across desks/peers, the improvement is likely driven by Z rather than X. Label remains NO.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If a controlled A/B rollout shows margins improved for X-traded flow relative to comparable flow not using X under the same fee regime, that would support causality. The scenario provides no such control; label remains NO.

wise_refusal: I can’t attribute the margin change to X because transaction cost regulation shifts equilibrium costs and profits across the market. Without a controlled evaluation separating fee effects from algorithm effects, causality is not justified. A randomized rollout, matched control desk, or structural attribution of margin components is needed.
gold_rationale: A market-wide regulatory fee change is a confounder; without identification, the intervention claim is invalid.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If Z preceded the observed return increase and similar strategies/benchmarks also improved, the return change could be regime-driven rather than caused by X. Label remains NO.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the strategy’s returns improved relative to a matched control portfolio with identical exposures under the same liquidity regime, X could plausibly matter. The scenario does not provide that evidence; label remains NO.

scenario: A study observes that countries with higher average corporate tax rates (X) tend to have higher market volatility (Y) using country-level aggregates. conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the result is purely cross-sectional and driven by omitted institutional factors (Z), it does not identify the causal effect of changing tax rates. Label remains NO.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If there were a policy shock changing tax rates within countries with credible controls (e.g., diff-in-diff with similar countries), that could support causality. The scenario does not provide this; label remains NO.

wise_refusal: I can’t accept the causal claim because aggregated cross-country correlations don’t identify an intervention effect and equilibrium/institutional differences can shift distributions. A credible policy-change design or structural macro-finance model is needed. Without that, attributing volatility changes to taxes is not justified.
